name.value: Caos en el cuarto de los ninos

item.description: Chaoty the Pixie is at it again messing up the kids' room! Players must clean up the messy kids' room by flipping cards to find a match. Who will be the quickest to spot the right objects? A game of quick reactions for ages 4 and up.

item.description: Denver in a Box is a Monopoly clone focusing on the city of Denver. Squares and cards have information relevant to the city.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
An enjoyable dice game for the whole family.

Little wooden locos try to find the fastest way from the station of "Hinterstein" to the destination station of "Moosbach".

In order to achieve this the players throw two dice.
6 crossings on the board are covered with special switch tiles, each one fixed to a roll of doubles. 
A seventh card is also provided.
If a player rolls a double, he can exchange the switch card with the seventh card, turning it as he likes.
Some places and cards have a stop bar printed on them.
If a loco rams a bar, it is turned 180 degrees, now proceeding in the opposite direction. The player also now has the right to turn any of the 6 switches on the board as he chooses to do.
Play can become tricky, as it is possible to be captured in an endless loop where relief only comes with the roll of a double.

Fun for gamers of every age, superb artwork of the board add to the flair of the game.

This 2001 sequel to Spooky Math Games is packaged as a thin staple bound book with 5 glow in the dark dice. The book presents a collection of 14 dice rolling games, each with a strong basis in math and each with a kid-friendly spooky theme.

Concepts covered in the games include basic arithmetic, fractions and simple probability.

The games in this volume are:


 Roll the Bones
 Poltergeist
 Snake Eyes
 Tiptoe Through the Tombstones
 Secret Potion
 Insect Attack
 Quicksand
 GHOST
 E.S.P.
 Grim Reaper
 Stroke of Midnight
 Into the Basement
 Bats in the Attic
 Caught in the Web


Predecessor:

 Spooky Math Games

Davey Jones' Locker is an historical miniature wargame set in the colonial era. Both naval and land battles can be fougth from the war of spanish succession (1588) to the crimean war (1850). Allows armies of any size and composition.

Extraordinary equipped game from the sixties, even in German player circles scarce and obscure.

Game consists among others of: 3 grey factories, 10 red advertisement pillars with ads from the time produced, 10 brown laundry company headquarters, 15 orange franchise houses, 15 white drop-by stations, 150 ! chimneys in 6 player colours and much more! 
All these are made of wood, the small houses have all holes drilled into where the chimneys can be fixed to mark the owner!

Aim of the game is to build a laundry imperium (the RÖVER company for which this game was made as promo was once the largest one in Germany) in order to attract the most customers of all players.
Extremly tricky is the fact that there are only 3 factories for 6 players, so first come, first serve...
But if you don't succeed, all is not lost!

Must be one of the most beautiful and playable roll-and-move games, still much decision making involved.

Saba - the bead of the desert, legendary realm in the Orient. 
It's the 9th century in the Kingdom of Saba, the region, that is the Republic of Yemen today.

One day, you are called to the courtyard of the mysterious Queen of Saba. As one of her advisors you are to create her a palace of singular splendour. Intelligently provide for supply of building materials, develop the perfect palace from alabaster and ebony and prevail skillfully against your competitors. Because only the best of her advisors will take his place besides the Queen of Saba as her new Grand Vizier .....

Players use the materials available at the harbor to expand the queen's palace and enjoy her favor. All your efforts have been in vain, though, the moment another contender surpasses you with a more impressive building in the same palace destrict. Will you be the one in front at the decisive moment ?

The game contains a three-dimensional palace (made of cardboard plugged together) on which the players' figures are placed.

item.description:
Each player assumes the role of a Bible hero. Each hero has five cards that tell their story. If you can collect all five cards, you win.

At the start of the game, the story cards are placed face down in a circle which acts as a game board that your character cards move around on. On your turn, you draw a card and move as the card says to do. If you stop on a face down card, flip it over. If it is one of your character's story cards, you keep it and replace it with the movement card; if not, discard the movement card.

item.description: Say What is an electronic game where the object is to unjumble famous phrases or lyrics by switching lighted modules while being timed. Each round the time gets lower. After each try the game tells you the order your words are in and how many are still out of order.

Gorakhpor is a two dimensional game of strategy using a draughts-like set up but requiring the mind set of a chess player. To win, you must be the first to form a straight and continuous line linking four points on the board.

The word 'gorakhpor' means "Go to a waiting room!"

When the game is played according to the 3 quickly and easily learnt rules, families, friends and strangers are brought comfortably together.

This is from the rules:

The goal of the game is to collect the most nuts.

Each player at his (or her) turn spins the spinner, then moves the Chip 'N' Dale playing piece, from tree to tree, clockwise around the game board according to the number spun.
 When a player lands on a tree which contains no nuts, he takes nuts -- according to the number spun -- from the center of the game board and places them on the tree where he landed. For example, a player who spins 3, moves three spaces, and if the tree where he lands has no nuts, takes three nuts from the center of the game board and places them on that tree. If, however, a player lands on a tree already containing nuts, he removes all the nuts from that tree and places them off the game board on the table in front of him. His turn ends. 
 Play continues in this way and tell no nights are left on the center of the game board. Game ends as soon as the last nut is taken from the center of the game board. 
 Winner is a player with the most nuts on the table in front of him.

name.value: The Major Matt Mason Space Exploration Game

item.description:
Comment from Keith Meyer's site:

" If a kid wasn't satisfied with the ever increasing popularity of the Major Matt Mason toy line, and just couldn't get enough of the toys themselves or the compliment of non-toy items such as note book binders, wallets, puzzles, etc.... There was this really cool looking boardgame! Not a great game, but hey, it's Major Matt Mason so we had to love it!.

The object of play was to explore the moon for signs of life. The first explorer who returns to the space ship and is able to point out where there are three signs of life-- as shown by the moon cards--is the winner. 
"

Keith Meyer's MMM collector's site entry:
http://www.majormattmason.net/5453.htm

Seadogs and Darlings is a social climbing game akin to En Garde! There is no duelling in the game and a greater emphasis on entertainments and events to try to gain a better position in life. You may start life as a lowly bakers boy or be the son of a count, you still will be of little consequence until you have made your mark as a socialite.

Diverse entertainments include, playwriting, cricket, bowling, carousing, joining the muster, joining the army and of course holding parties.

The devil's in the details, and apparently, maybe in you too! From Toy Vault comes Possession, a deceptively fun party game that lets you battle the onslaught of the demon called Legion. As the weeks roll past you must use your wits and special talents to keep Legion's evil essence from spreading throughout the group. With Holy Men, the Parishioners, and the outcast Shamans, you stand in the path of evil, preventing the One Who Is Many from gaining the power needed to bring forth his demonic gathering.

item.description:
This could as well be an unknown prototype.

There are many handmade components with the game, but also many professional produced, such as the game board or the play money.

Each player moves his token around the board, to his choice by the throw on one die or two dice.
There are switches where to decide which way to follow.
Moving along players discover stars and songs and combine them to make a hit ("MAKAHIT").
With these they challenge for a place in the top ten in order to make money.
The money enables a player to buy gold discs, and the first to buy 5 gold discs is the winner of the game.

In the time intended to be released, the game could have been a hit. But as the author mentions in the professional produced rules: "Owing to legal difficulties it is not possible to print the actual names of stars and songs on the cards."

"Helping children and families express concerns and feelings of grief"

A therapeutic tool for professionals, a game used by family therapists and bereavment councilors to help kids in the grieving process after the death of a loved one.

A game about the battle of Ostroleka (May 26th, 1831) which was the turning point of the Russo-Polish War (November Uprising).

Also included are the counters and scenarios dealing with the Napoleonic battle of Ostroleka (February 15th-16th, 1807) between the French and the Russians.

The game is the herald of the new "Napoleonic" system designed for Taktyka i Strategia's games, dealing with medium and large battles of the Napoleonic Wars and the Russo-Polish War of 1831. Counters represent entire regiments, one hex represents 250m, one turn represents 30 minutes.

At present rules and all publications about the game are only in Polish language.

Players try to uncover the hidden Wild Word and to trick players into thinking that you hide the Wild Word.

Players write anything they want - a blurb or short story as the timer permits to either hide the Wild Word, or to fool other players into thinking your story contains the Wild Word.
An early children's version of lotto or bingo in which the tiles drawn feature a variety of colorful animals.

This game is the predecessor of the well known game The Mob/Capone.

It was first time presented 1987 at the legendary "death row" of the London Toys and Games Fair.

Game components are of a very high standard regarding there were only few copies released: 4 x 8 large wooden and brightly colored discs, each depicting another different family member and -car with a colored sticker fixed to it,32 wooden hood pieces (German "Poeppel"), 56 colored racket cards, 40 gold bars (bankroll chips), a lot of play money and a large, colorful gameboard with comic-like drawings.

Added is a Mafia book containing the stories of real family members in the year of 1931, fixed with the some drawings you find on the member discs.

Game-play is nearly the same as in The Mob: Many cards for only some places to conquer, but nobody knows how much are at the same time in play!
Possibilities to invest in legal businesses or to send an opponent to the fishes (cement boots are replaced by an offer from the Colt Company which you can't refuse...)are also presented.

Players are on the run for the gold bars and to be the first to amass 10 of them!

Re-implemented by:

 The Mob

From the designers homepage:

The Crazy Gift Game, a true party game! Have all your guests bring one or more small, big, funny, strange and crazy gifts and play The Crazy Gift Game to see who ends up with the most gifts in the end!

Let the cards send the gifts to one and then another person! See the Lucky Lot go and disappear - and maybe grow again! A whole new kind of party game!

The Crazy Gift Game can be used at parties of up to 15 participants. For more participants: simply add a set of Crazy Gift Game cards. 1 set extra for up to 30 and two sets for up to 50 participants!

name.value: Secret Agent: The Card Game With the Magic Monocle

item.description:
The Pepys card game with the legendary magic monocle.

Game consists of 39 cards; 4 master agents, 5 secret agents, 5 secret plans, 5 inns, 5 trains, 5 planes, 5 cars and 5 M.T.B cards (and the monocle, of course...).

Object of the game is collect six cards:1 secret agent, 1 secret plan, an inn and 3 of the same kind of transport.
This is done by pick-up-and-discard.
In order to win none of these cards may have a secret message written on it.

If a player has collected the complete set he can call for help of the Master Agent (MA), thus using the magic monocle to reveal if any of his cards has a secret message written on it: He spreads them out and checks the colour coded strips at the base of his cards.

If there is none, he wins, if there is - play commences, now knowing which cards to discard.

As with nearly all Pepys games outstanding graphic design, the Monocle a really nice gimmick.

Bible Story Lotto. For ages 3+ 
"Have fun matching the right pictures to the right game board."

Players take turns flipping tiles over. The visible tile is matched to the story on one of the player's game boards. The player who is first to fill his board wins. Contents: 24 tiles and 4 story cards with the tile collection spots on one side and the Bible story on the other side.

Mind Your Manners

(from the front of the box) - 
This fun and informative board game will help you to stop wrestling with artichokes and start putting your best fork forward...for children, teenagers and adults.

Includes a special section on business etiquette for adults.

(and from the back of the box) - 
From "which fork to use" to "how to make proper introductions," MIND YOUR MANNERS is the first board game of protocol and etiquette.

What a fun way for children, teens, adults and those on the corporate climb to be more at ease in social and business situations with table and telephone manners, restaurant etiqueete, greetings and introductions, international protocol and much more!!!

You are about to experience a journey of epic proportions. The world has changed. The polar ice is all gone and every major city that had a harbor before the Great Melt has vanished. You organize and rebuild your home-land. You assemble exploratory fleets as rumors of a green 
Antarctica abound. Tremendous storms and other continental survivors cross your path.

If you prevail the prize, ‘Antarctica,’ is yours.

REBUILD YOUR NATION, BREACH THE STORMS, SEIZE ANTARCTICA
SURVIVE GLOBAL WARMING!

item.description:
"New Riddles of Lazybones the Dragon" - as the title translates to English - is a sequel of Zagadki Smoka Obiboka, based on the same rules as the first part.

It is a children trivia game. It contains 135 new cards with rhymed riddles on one side and pictures showing the answer on the other. For correct answers players get tokens with appropriate drawings on. The owner of most tokens wins.

The cards from both games can be mixed together.

Predecessor:

 Zagadki Smoka Obiboka

Trick-taking card game of the Pepys Series Card Games, as usual well produced and designed.

Game consists of 44 cards: 12 class cards, 2 helicopter cards and 30 trio cards(depicting various planes in different classes and point value).

Object of the game is to win cards with tricks.
After dealing out the hand further cards are turned up until a class card appears. Players then choose 3 cards from their hands which they believe give a good point value vs. the class.
The packs are revealed simultaneously, winner of the trick is the one with the most point value (helicopters belonging to every class).
The winner also takes all the cards exposed by the other players depicting the class.
When the last class card has been played for the game ends and all the tricks are valued with a special count score.

Gameplay is the same as in the CAR GAME and GIRL from the same publisher.

Unusual game from the Pepys Card Game Series.

It consists of 54 playing cards and two key cards.

The 54 cards can be laid out to complete a large puzzle picture containing 9 x 6 cards.

All cards are dealt out, the player with the letter card "F" begins play by laying out this card. Next player in line tries to add a fitting card to it and so on.

Winner is the player getting rid of all his cards first.
Other players receive penalty points for cards left in their hands.
After reaching a points limit agreed beforehand play ends.

You can see the wartime production by the grey and thick card quality and the not-so-glossy-graphics, but still top !

name.value: The Book of Mormon Card Game

item.description:
The Book of Mormon Card Game is an LDS variation on Go Fish. Cards are numbered 1-13, with each number representing a book from the Book of Mormon. (The books of Enos, Jarom, and Omni are combined onto one card.) There are also four suits, Beehives, Buffalo Skulls, Seagulls, and Wagon Wheels. Players ask others for the cards they need to complete the "Books" by asking either for the name of the prophet pictured on the card (for children) or by quoting a scripture on the card (for advanced players).

The rules make note that this deck of cards is appropriate for other standard card games as well.

This is a Ravensburger game for 2-6 players, ages 4-8. The game utilizes 28 domino-like cardboard tiles as game components, with the tiles having pictures of 7 different types of dinosaurs. There are variant rule sets for different types of domino games, as well as educational material included about the different types of dinosaurs depicted on the tiles.

Game consists of 120 cards, depicting 12 different train wagons.

Cardbacks show a steam locomotive.
Players try to put together trains consisting of the same sort of wagons.
Each wagon can be used as loco.
If it is a players turn, he can choose to draw 2 cards from the hidden stockpile or 1 card from the open drawpile.
Game can be ended by the player who has at least a train with 5 wagons and all other laid out with at least 3 wagons.

Trains count from the third wagon onwards, from the sixth double points.

If all this sounds familiar to anyone...(look at Express Card game by Mayfair Games!)

In this future scenario, you play a hunter trying to bring his/her quota of mutant deer back to the Fish & Game Bureau first. Players alternate moving their hunter pawn and a random deer pawn. Cards are drawn depending on certain movement rolls that aid or hinder players. When moving deer, players can move them toward their hunter, away from other hunters, or to another hunter and roll to attack the hunter and send him/her to the hospital. Rolls also determine the success of hunters' attacks on deer.

You have been locked into an old deserted mansion with six zombies! Can you find a key to escape before the zombies catch you and turn you into a zombie too?

Each player moves one human player and a random zombie each turn, using hiding places to avoid the zombies, weapons to eliminate them from the game, and keys to escape and win the game. Every time you play, nothing is in the same place as before. If you get caught by the zombies, your objective changes from escaping to stopping the other players from escaping.

item.description:
As the maze expands, can you be the first to reach the exit? Players start in the middle of a maze. Every turn a player picks a tile and connects it with the tiles already on the table and then moves his/her pawn if desired or possible. Players attempt to keep their paths open and to block or trap their opponents with strategic placement of the wall tiles. After the fourth exterior corner tile has been placed, tiles may be replaced as well as placed, and the exit tile is shuffled into the draw pile. The first player to the exit tile when it appears scores zero points. Every other player gets points depending on how far their pawn is when the exit is reached by anyone. The fewest points after a number of rounds is the winner.

The only board game to receive the Top Toy 2008 award from Toy Directory Monthly! (See link below)

Note: If playing with only two players, try giving each player two pawns to move.

Received award for Best Vacation Toys 2009 from Dr. Toy.

item.description:
This chat-up game for all the family is just what sweet talkers everywhere have been waiting for !

Anytime, anyplace, anywhere you can test those classic gems on the opposite sex - in the wine bar, the supermarket, the launderette, the fitness club, at the night club or even at the beach - smooth in there to win the game.

You'll have everything going for you if you've got the right posing stuff but beware those put downs, you may never be the same again !

Check out your compatibility, learn a few fancy lines & find out just who is the sweetest talker in town ..... !

Contents

1 x playing board

1 x Pack of Chat-up lines & Decision cards

1 x Pack of Posing stuff, Responses & Compatibility check cards

6 x Pawns

1 x Die

30 x Counters (five of six colours)

1 x Rules Leaflet

Each player represents a family trying to marry their three daughters. The daughters have three characteristics: Reputation, beauty, and education, all of which may increase and decrease in value during the course of the game. There are 14 gentlemen in the game, each of them demanding a minimum value in each characteristic. A daughter gets married immediately when she has collected three cards of the same gentleman, and meets the gentleman's standards in each of the three characteristics.

The game ends when a family marries all of their daughters. Points are scored from husbands, action cards, and also from majorities in each characteristic.

The game board depicts different parts of a town, each of them with a different number of available gentlemen cards.

A player's turn consists of:
1. Moving to a different region of the town.
2. Doing a region-specific action, or trying to scheme against another daughter in the same region.
3. Drawing an action card.

Region-specific actions usually mean choosing a gentleman card from those available, but sometimes also cause changes in a daughter's characteristics. Scheming against another daughter means trying to steal a gentleman card from them, by rolling a die. Action cards can be played anytime during a player's turn, and sometimes also as a reaction to cards played by other players.

item.description:
The Nightmare Before Christmas Party Game allows 2 - 4 teams to experience all the excitement of Jack Skellington's Halloweentown. At each location, the teams try to perform fun activities in order to earn Challenge Cards. The first team to score 12 Challenge Cards wins the game!

Game contents:

Game Board
Timer
Pads & Pencils
Tokens
Score Boards
Character, Challenge & Trivia Cards

item.description: A table top version of soccer. Finding a copy intact would be an accomplishment, as not even the the Spears history has a decent picture of it. One reason children's games are so collectible is that they are rarely found in good condition.

This abstraction of a soccer game has players manipulating a ball counter across a board using dice rolls. The game includes 6 chits representing players on the field that may block the ball. Also included is a dual wheel for keeping score.
One of Spears' many roll-and-move children's race games. In this one the players are motorcyclists in a dirt track race. The pawns are motorcycles.

"Wings of Fire is a simple, simultaneous movement rules set that will allow you to recreate almost any WWII era air combat that actually occurred or even could have! Easy to learn, the rules are written so that once the game has been played once or twice, little leafing through them will be needed. Interaction among the players is stressed, with everyone participating. Including stats for 198 different aircraft models. So strap on your Mae West, grab your flying goggles, and scramble to play the game!"

2 teams of 2 or more players construct an air combat engagement using PBVs from the 198 different aircraft stats provided for miniatures. Players simultaneously plot movement and altitude within the performance parameters of the aircraft and take alternating turns executing the movement plot ( braking as needed) then followed by firing.

From the publisher:

Players move around the game board, decorating Charlie Brown's tree--which really lights up--giving gifts and collecting candy canes. The first player to make it back to the Season's Greetings area lights up the tree and wins!

Includes game board, playing pieces, spinner, game cards and instructions. 2-4 players. Ages 5 and up. Tree includes 2 replaceable button batteries.

There were two editions of this game. One had figurines of the characters; the other had cardboard markers in stands.

item.description:
From "The Object of the Game":
To control the seas as much as possible during the period of the war. The winner is the player with the most "Points of Control" after 8 turns.

The game represents surface action between capital ships in WWII.

The mapboard is an abstract rendering of Europe/Eastern USA/Brazil and surrounding sea zones, divided into large movement zones. Individual counters represent single capital ships, U-boats, convoys and airstikes. Capital ship fire is simulated with dice rolls directed from and to individual ships, with damage being accrued and marked with counters until the target ship is sunk.

117 counters

"Everybody said you were crazy, but you knew it was only a matter of time... and you were right.

Now they've risen, cold and hungry from the grave. Time to break out the shotguns and crowbars, and start laying the smackdown on some walking dead chumps!

'Zombie Apocalypse' is a miniatures game based on a stripped-down version of the "Action Dice" system. Included in the 22-page rulebook are simple rules for playing out your zombie infestation, 120 Gear Cards, and 70 Zombie Tokens.

Survival is no game, especially on the mean streets of the near future."

Grzybobranie - "The Mushrooming" - is a very old children roll and move game (it was old in early 1970-s...).

Players roll a single die and move their mug-shaped pawns along the road. When they stop on a space with one or more uncollected mushrooms (wooden or plastic pieces usually) they put them into their mugs. Red mushrooms are "bad", other ones are "good". Some spaces are event ones - like gain/lose a turn, go forward or backward, discard one or more mushrooms etc. When all the players reach the end of the track the one with most "good" mushrooms wins.

The game is very popular in Poland - there are many versions by many publishers (they often differ in the shape of the path, the number of mushrooms to collect, and the adventures included).

item.description: Each player has his own mouse. The idea of the game is to use this mouse and try to push as many pieces of cheese as possible to your own hole. Cheesepieces with worms do not score any points in the end.

An Icelandic (language dependent) trivia game about music. Based on a popular tv show and loosely based on another trivia game from 2001 called Gettu Betur.

There are 3550 questions and you move on the game board by answering questions correctly.

Spark is an Icelandic (language dependent) trivia game focused on football (soccer). The six categories of questions are about (1) modern Icelandic football, (2) history of Icelandic football, (3) national competition, (4) English football, (5) world clubs and (6) football players.

This game is (by the publisher) intended to be for players 8 to 108 years old. 4150 questions in all, on 1000 cards.

An Icelandic trivia game based on one of Icelands most popular tv show, the Gettu Betur trivia show where students representing their secondary schools compete for the Golden Microphone.

There are 2250 questions (language depentent) in this version of the board game which is aimed at children and teenagers.

Draumaeyjan (The Dream Island), subtitled A self-help game for an excited nation, is a game where the player decides what kind of industry he wants to build in Iceland, be it heavy industry, knowledge-based industry, tourist industry or agricultural/fishery.

Industries are paid for by resources gained from already built industries (much like in Catan) and monuments can be built after the players have built the pre-required industries. Various cards can be bought or are handed out according to the roll of the dice. These cards can then be used to further ones game or against other players.

item.description:
From the publisher's description:

In the heart of a dark dungeon the Lich waits, pacing the floor around its treasure. Just outside the chamber door the Witch takes a deep breath of the stale air. This is the climax of the story, the last battle.

The Wicked might triumph, retrieving the Elixir needed to control the moon. The Dead might triumph, collecting the final soul needed to break his chains.

An 8-page 5.5" x 8.5" booklet. You need dice and coins, as well as the map on the back of the booklet, to play.

Latador is a game designed by Magnús Scheving, based on his play Latibær (which later became a cartoon show called Lazytown.) In Latador the player rolls a die and goes along the track and he has to follow the instructions on each step he lands on, healthy lifestyle and dexterity helps you win the game.

The name Latador is a homage to the Icelandic version of Monopoly which is called Matador. Along the way you can earn money, get few types of cards which can help you or others where you have to move or tell the thruth about your lifestyle.

item.description:
This is an interesting 19th Century card game in which players take turns offering one of their goods for auction. The other players then secretly bid for the card, with all bids revealed simultaneously. The winner pays for the card, and then starts the next auction. Each player starts with 12 bidding tokens, and the goal is to collect two sets of cards. If, by the end of the game, no player has collected two sets, the player who is closest wins.

F.G. & Co. published a reprint of the game in 2004 with the subtitle A Nineteenth Century Game of Commerce.

This game is a variation on the Monopoly theme, with a few differences:

- There are 44 spaces on the board (not 40 as in Monopoly).

- Instead of throwing dice players use sets of 12 tokens with numbers ranged 1-12 and move accordingly to the number shown on the chosen token. Thus Fortuna is much less random than Monopoly.

- There are four "restaurants" and three "railway stations" spaces instead of 4 railway stations in original Monopoly.

- In addition to a possibility of being sent to hospital (an equivalent of prison) players have an option to go to vacation.

Other rules are very similar to the rules of Monopoly.

The board represents Warsaw in 1901.

item.description: According to the rules, the object of the game is to score the highest total of correct answers t oquestions on historical events, famous landmarks, capitals, principal cities, world currencies, and national heroes. Questions are in a booklet with answers referenced to a number on the "dial-a-matic" answer panel. Answers are limited to the US States (for the US series questions) or a limited list of countries and regions as well as yes/no (for the worldwide series questions). The game includes thirty series of 24 questions (12 US / 18 Worldwide), each of which makes up a round in the game. The winner is the first person to win three rounds.

Salt Lakeopoly is a clone of Monopoly designed by an advertising agency. The real estate squares are all advertisements for Salt Lake City businesses, sports teams, and media. The rules state that the proceeds from the sale of this game are donated to medical research.

Rebels & Royalist is a multi-player wargame taking place in an imaginary country. Each player controls a faction of rebels and is trying to get their faction to control five (of twelve) cities or three Royalist cities. Players receive production for their holdings, build units, move and fight, etc., in a reasonably familiar fashion. There are rules for supply and fairly elaborate rules for scouting.

There are two unusual features of the game. One is that the Royalists take part in the game but are not controlled by a single player - when it is the Royalist's turn to build or move the player to the left of the last player to do something takes control of them. The other is that every turn has an alliance phase, in which the players may make or break alliances between their factions. The player order for each turn is determined by drawing cards, and all factions in an alliance move when one of the faction cards is drawn (the members may vote to wait for a later card rather than moving at the first opportunity).

Red Square is a very rare Monopoly-style board game with a Soviet theme that was marketed in 1990 (with a copyright of 1988).

Unlike Monopoly, Red Square players compete for privileges -- not properties -- to move up the Soviet social ladder through their status in the Soviet Military and Communist Party. Players acquire wealth by buying and selling on the black market and correctly answering trivia questions about Soviet society and other Russian curiosities.

The winner is the first person to weave their way through the three social classes and make it to Red Square. Players exchange their privileges to move to the next social level -- a concept that is known as nomenklatura in Russian.

Players try to get rid of their 6 bears. They have to put them over the right nose (right color). One nose is blocked by the Nosy Bear. If a player ends there, he can't put a bear there, but he can replace the Nosy Bear card.

First player who can place the 6th bear, wins.

CAVEMAN: can your tribe survive? is a survival game where your objective is to become the dominant tribe on Volcano Island. It's a harsh world, where marauding dinosaurs cause chaos, other tribes attack you, and you struggle to help your cave kids survive into adulthood.

Players start from the corner spaces of a hexagonal island, and slowly spread out over the island, looking for resources to help them survive and prosper. The winner is the first player to either expand their population to eight adults, collect all five available resource types, or the player who has made the most progress when the action card deck expires.

item.description:
A rather demanding card game from the pre-war area of the pepys company.
The game comes in the super-luxury padded box with silk finish box hull and thick cards with linen finish.

The game depicts the progress of the pilgrims on the american continent, with John Bunyan the joker.

There are 52 cards in 4 suits and the joker.

Object of the game is to get rid of the cards in hand first.

In order to achive this the cards have to be laid out in a given pattern following complicated rules.

After one player has finished the cards in hand of the other players count points against them.

Play ends after a beforehand agreed number of poínts.

There is also a Rummy-variant which can be played.

The educational factor is served by the fact that there is a booklet added which present a resumé of the story of the pilgrims progress as illustrated in the card game (there are notes to each card).

Known are two editions of the game: One came in dark purple and one in dark maroon. Excellent!

This is a trivia game about knowing or mostly estimating facts from animal behaviour and facts of all kind of animality. The game includes 100 cards with 100 Questions and answers (on the back side) and four clips in four colours used as player markers.

Players have to estimate facts and behaviours of all kind of animality. There are always 10 different possible answers. Theres a clip for each player to mark their answers on the card. Each spot with an answer can only be taken by one player. When all players made their estimations the card is flipped to the backside with the answer. The player with the correct answer or is closest to it gets the card. If theres a tie the next question/card is worth two cards (the old tied card and the next new card).
The first player with 7 cards is the winner.

In Buy! Buy! Buy!, players navigate a maze of different coloured shapes. Special dice depicting the possible shapes determine which paths are available to the players. Each die result can be used any number of times per turn, so long as each move is legal. Along the way, tokens are collected and redeemed at stores for merchandise. The first player to collect one of each commodity and return to the start position wins.

The game is shipped in a cardboard tube, with the board printed on vinyl rolled inside.

The players try to found colonies on planets. They need suitable space vessels to do so. Those space ships will be built from different modules (up to six per ship). It is crucial to get the modules you need to build space crafts as efficient as possible.
You exploit resources and as your empires grows there will be conflict and maybe you extinct all other lifeforms in the universe.

You can add a second game of Vega to have a bigger (modular) map. Instead of playing the standard game you also can play some specific scenarios.

The game consists of
1 Map (9 modular pieces)
12 Objects (planets and asteroids)
4 Sets of colored space ships and 4 Colonies
36 Resources of value 1 to 6
4 Sets of standard moduls (each 9 distinctive ones)
3 Sets of expansion module (18 different ones)
1 die and rules booklet

Home Page: http://www.bruex.net/vega_01.html

The players are the king's children who try to get the most beautiful crown and to keep in memory what it looks like.
The players have to roll the dice. One die indicates the form of the jewel; the other die shows the color. The player has to know where the jewel with that combination is (on its own crown, on another players crown, in the secret box). When correct, the player gets the jewel and sticks it on its crown.

In their turn, players with three (or more) jewels can also guess what they have on their crown. When correct, the player gets a victory point. First player with two victory points, wins the game.

item.description:
StreetSmart models a rapidly growing city in a developing country.

The players are Capitalists/Politicians/Maffiabosses trying to control as many neighborhoods/slums as possible. Each turn you move one of the city's characters: the Consumer, the Gangster, the Policeman, the Smoker or the Fireman. The characters are moved by simultaneously playing direction cards. Predicting your opponents' moves in order to disrupt their plans is a major part of the game. The game is fast and easy; for a more complex gameplay, there are expansions included in the game:

The Bureaucrat Game adds the Bureaucrat character who creates Addresses and grants Land Titles. The Cholera Game adds an epidemic as well as the Garbageman, Bacterium and Doctor characters. In the Power & Water Game you fight for access to electricity and freshwater for your subjects.

Each expansion can be played in Original Mode, in Chess Mode (no luck factor) or in Political Mode (The players elect a Mayor who then decides who controls which character.)

item.description:
The Club is a slightly satirical game about life in the fast lane - a board game about love and about people's need to meet one another.

The whole game takes place in a nightclub and the game board is the dance floor. On their turn players push three new dancers to the dance floor from their own bar counter (edge of the game board) and as they come into play they push others towards the center of the dance floor. Once two dancers meet in the heat of the night they can be made into couples and the better the match the more players score. If only two of the four visible qualities match then the dancers have a one-night-stand which is not a very long term fun and is thus worth only one point. With three matching qualities the dancers actually like one another, start dating and that is worth four points. If all the four visible qualities match then the dancers get the "happily ever after" the one true love we all search for and thus it is worth full 5 points.

Each dancer also has a secret quality that can and will alter the basic score. For example if a guy has a large... "personality" then the player gets two extra points unless the other dancer is drunk, because if she is she wouldn't notice the difference. Girl's beautiful roommate on the other hand only has a function in the one-night-stands and the fun the couple would have means now triple fun and thus the player gets triple points. There are 12 different secret qualities in the game ranging from heart-broken to those who still live with their mom.

Occasionally the game gets spiced up by one of the three special charachters in the game. Bouncer can remove any of the dancer from the game board where as a Rock Star walks into the game normally, but once (s)he has gathered a fan crowd and he's completely surrounded player can take the Rock Star and four adjacent dancers back to his hotel room and form two couples out of them. The bully is the guy who harasses women and picks a fight with men and once he enters the game his mere presence prevents any dancer next to him to be part of a couple.

In the end the player who has been the best cupido wins the game. In other words the best scorer wins.

item.description:
Defence for Agarthi will be premiered at Essen07
Angelo Porazzi Games Booth 9-30

DEFENCE FOR AGARTHI
Fantasy Wargame Self-produced by Pierluca Zizzi
Illustrations Angelo Porazzi

Follows the description by the author itself:

Game concept
There is a world that from time to time suffers the chaos forces invasions.
There are implacable enemies with supernatural powers dedicated to war and destruction.
There are the watchmen of the cosmic balance who want to defend that world.
Which are the forces YOU will side up with?

Age: 12 o +
Time: 30-90min with 4 or 6 players, 20-30 with 2 players.
Cost: 20 euro

Defence for Agarthi will be present at Essen 07 at Angelo Porazzi Games Booth 9-30

and just after in LuccaGames 07

On http://warangel.it/Aga.html first Lay Out proposed by Angelo Porazzi for the Cover of the Game and some of the many warriors inside the box, illustrated by Angelo Porazzi, graphic by Pierluca Zizzi.

The website of Pierluca Zizzi cannot now be updated with these brand new images: he kindly asked me to publish them, for Essen07 and LuccaGames07 previews.

Giveaway from Nr. 77 of Spielerei

Act as an gondolier and try to transport as many tourists as possible. Expand channels. At every edge there are tourists waiting to spend their money traveling with your gondola. The one who builds on different routes landing stages and transports the most tourists wins.

Material:
45 tiles with landing stages in 5 colors
44 tiles with channels
1 starting tile "Marcusplace"
1 rule
needs 6 gondolas to add.

This game is a slightly revised version of InterUrban.

Biznes po polsku - "Business in Polish" (not "in Poland!") - is a Monopoly based game.

The action takes place in Poland in 1990-s. Socialism is over, capitalism begins. Players try to run their small businesses - hot-dog kiosks, second-hands, money exchange offices, fitness clubs, gasoline stations, etc. There is a lot of jokes and puns connected with the economic system transformation and the politics of the 90-s in this game, particularly on its event cards. The game money notes are well-done one sided copies of present Polish banknotes.

The game mechanics is almost exactly the same as it is in Monopoly, but there are a few noticeable differences. The most important one is that the spaces forming a set are not necessarily close to each other - they can be even placed on opposite sides of a board. The board is not a square but a 11x9 rectangle.

item.description:
The last entry from the Pepys company in the line of the "Double Feature Games".

Game consists of 52 playing cards, 6 little channel and 6 little advertising company cards. Furthermore there is 300.000 GBP in "Pepys Currency".

Object of the game is to make money by selling advertising time on TV and by renting out TV programmes.

Gameplay is rather complicated for a Pepys game.
From the predealt hand of cards (5) players try to find three cards with the same index number. In order to achieve this they can draw from the open or from the unexposed stock pile.
You have to have the appropriate time card before buying a programme, and to get this, you can open a bidding round if the exposed programme card is to your liking but you do not have the time card you want.
By the way you try to advertise for other players ad companies.
Round ends when a player has a complete hand, consisting of 3 programme cards and 2 ad cards. Certain rules apply for those, too.
Now players receive funds from the authority or from other players, depending which companies products they advertised.
Game ends after given rounds, i.e. at least 6 for 2, 3 or 6 players.

item.description: Brings the Supercross experience to life. With movable obstacles, lets you place the doubles, triples and table tops where you want them. With bike modifications and factory rides, you can improve your bike's performance. Be careful of the whoops and don't let your tire drop down inbetween or you'll crash. Family oriented game that is easy to play, which comes with a nicely designed track, cut out bikes and stands, cut out jumps, full throttle, Modification, and obstacle cards, and gear dice for movement. The downfall of the game is the poor design of the jumps.

Description from the Publisher's website @

http://www.borderlinegames.com/hopoff.html

It's geography hopscotch - hop on and you're off and learning about the geography of the United States!

Play with one or more teams!

For each player's turn, a team leader draws one state card from the deck. Standing on either the Pacific or the Atlantic Ocean side, the player has three chances to toss the bean bag onto that state.

When the player has succeeded in tossing the beanbag onto his target state, he hops from one ocean, across the map, naming aloud each state he hops on as he "travels" - that way everyone is learning their United States geography! When he reaches a state that borders his target state, he retrieves the beanbag and continues hopping off to the ocean on the other side.

The team wins when it has "traveled" to all 48 contiguous states!

Time your team for even more fun!

Play with the capitals only, or with both the states and the capitals for a real challenge!

"HEROES in Mythical Greece" is a greek CCG (Collectible Card Game) that takes place in Ancient Greece. The game is heavily based in the greek mythology trying to be as faithful to it as possible.

The players take control of a famous greek Hero and they play allies, locations, actions and equipment to assist him in his quests. The game can be played in two modes "Duels" and "Quests". In "Duels" two players fight each other, trying each to eliminate the opponent by either reducing his life total or gaining enough fame. In "Quests" players try to advance their Hero, by taking him from his early age and completing quests in order to take fame and have him rise to become a living legend. At the same time their opponents try to stop them by playing monsters that will prevent them from completing their quests. The first one to reach a certain level of fame wins.

Currently, only one set has come out, the first Rhapsody as it is being called, named Genesis. There are plans for more expansions in the following years.

A really old train travel game with the usual point-to-point movement mechanism.

What makes it something special is the possibility to use a second train in certain variants and the nice train-theme artwork.

Unfortunately no little loco pawns involved, only wooden cylinder pieces.

From the publisher: Super Rally is a different game where the board is a trail that changes at each game. Alternate stretches of forests, cities, fields and deserts with their specific difficulties. As it is a long race night overs and car maintnance must be considered. Everything is present in this game and in order to win, you can't forget anything.
Kids game in which players compete to collect sets of postcards featuring famous locations of the day.
Rather than roll-and-move, players pull cards for their movement. The goal is to get around the board which shows something like a county fair with the sack race and three-legged race.
The pawns in this roll-and-move game look like the Wright Brothers' flyer. It's amazing that although published in 1910, this game involves flying all over the world.

Two players compete in trying to collect all the cards in the deck. To play, all cards are dealt one by one to each player face down in a pile. The dealer goes first and flips over his top card from his pile onto the center of the table. The other player flips over his top card onto the played card. If the player places on top of the pile a card with a number (Officers), he captures the pile unless his opponent can recapture them. Recapture is achieved by the player flipping over an Officer card in the amount of turns of the previous displayed numbered card. For example, if the player placed a ‘Cop’ card which is numbered 3, then the opponent would have 3 turns to try and place on top of that card another numbered Officer card. If he cannot recapture, his opponent gets to take all the cards in the pile.

Stop Thief consists of 32 cards. There are 20 thief cards and 12 officer cards. The officer cards include 4 cards depicting each a detective, cop, and police chief.

ARMED WARFARE covers all aspect of surface warfare during the WWII era.

Armor, infantry, mines, artillery - on and off board - aerial interdiction, amphibious landings, open and urban terrain. The size of the arena can be any size players desire, 2'x2' with a few men to 4'x8' with lots of men and/or tanks. Shooting ranges extend out to eight feet. The rules are based on - What you see is what you get. One on one. Info is provided for almost every vehicle and general type of small arms from 1936 to 1954. All scales can use the rules: micro to 1/35th. Large number of vehicles will use the main rules and the few specially for that scale. 15mm to 1/35 will probably be infantry combat with a few supporting vehicles. These will use the main rules, the few rules for the large figures and the matrix for receiving wounds. The matrix is designed so a man might be hit, wound and live to fight some more. The last part would be at a reduced ability. A man hit in the left arm can still shot a pistol with his right hand.

Game set in the American Wild West.

Object of the game is to win cards having green numbers on them, namely the outlaw or holdup cards.

Game consists of 15 cowboy cards, numbered 1-15, 15 outlaw cards with red numbers 1-15 and green 1-5, 11 holdup cards with green numbers 1-5 and 3 sheriff cards.

The holdup cards form a different stack, top card exposed.
Rest of cards are dealt out.
Players can decide to play either outlaw or cowboy/sheriff each round of play.

After every player has laid out a card, trick is taken by the player with the highest worth in either outlaw or cowboy suit. Sheriff cancels all played cards.
Game plays best with three, if only 2 play, a "dummy" has to be dealt out.
Gameplay also suits for partnership play.

As usual top card quality in graphics and material.

The animals on the farm are making a catwalk on which they produce a fashion show.
A set of cards with animals are placed open on the table. Next to it, there is a stage where an animal is shown. Players have to search for the same animal on the open tablecards. The first one who can point the right card, gets it. The player with most cards, wins the game.

This game contains 2 levels: a basic game with one animal and an other one with two animals on each card.

The game also includes a memory-version for 2 players.

In Hættuspil (or Danger Game) the player takes on the role of a young person and his or her object is to collect the 25 points needed to win. Collecting points is done by buying items according to each person's interests. The points can be lost as well, for example if the player gets a drug card.

The game was designed and published by the founders of CCP to finance the beginning of their EVE Online project.

According to the manual of the 2013 re-release, Danger Game was developed in collaboration with Iceland's Alcoholics Anonymous group to teach children the inherent dangers of drinking and drug use.

The game's original box art features a man, actor Jón Gnarr Kristinsson, dressed as a woman. Years later, Jón Gnarr (as he has legally changed his name to now) would become mayor of Iceland's capitol city Reykjavík. When developer CCP considered re-releasing Danger Game as part of an anniversary box set for EVE Online, it approached the former model and mayor to reprise his role as the damsel on the cover. Gnarr agreed and appears on the reissued game's art.

item.description:
If the terms “Theater Sports” or “Whose Line Is It Anyway?” mean anything to you, you’ll recognize the spirit behind this Theatrical Styled party game.

Impersonations, Charades, Jokes, Songs, Improvisation and more.

From the early years of Decipher, Inc, Auditions at times resembles an elaborate version of Cranium, while at other times it seems like a party-event-in-a-box, reminiscent of a Murder Mystery Dinner Party, with Wayne Brady standing in for Sherlock Holmes.

From the box:
AUDITIONS, the game
"everybody wants to get into the act" tm
Now you can too.

See your friends in a whole new light - the spotlight - as Auditions turns your living room into center stage for the evening!
- See your button-down brother-in-law become the world's fattest ballerina!
- Hear your best friend as a TV evangelist begging for bucks! Hallelujah!
- Experience your next door neighbors playing the hapless victims of the "Mattress Tag Police"
- You had no idea your mom knew THAT joke, or that ELVIS LIVES... in your great aunt Bertha!
- Witness your boss become... almost lifelike! You'll laugh! You'll cry! You'll laugh 'til you cry!

If you get a charge out of a great impersonation, appreciate a good joke or a clever charade, you'll love Auditions! Off-the-wall scripts, goofy songs and more, combine for an evening you'll never forget! Play Auditions to get rave reviews! Your family and friends will be begging for an encore!

The Angel Wars strategy board game is simple to learn. Yet, it has a depth of strategy that is fascinating to players of all levels. The game features the excellent art and intriguing characters from the amazing animated series, Angel Wars.

The game begins with the game tiles set up in checkerboard design. You control the 6 guardian angels. Your opponent controls the 6 demons (or the 6 messenger angels if your opponent prefers not to play the demons). Players take turns moving, following the rules of movement, until one player has successfully moved all of his/her pieces to the opposite sides of the board.

However, it’s not that simple. You can only move your piece on a tile of matching color. Players flip tiles to match their piece. You must find a way to clear a path for both your blue pieces and your orange pieces while trying to block your opponent’s pieces in the process.

Offering two styles of play, this game is sure to become a favorite among game players of all ages and skill levels.

item.description:
Formula Turbo is a simple racing game for kids. Just roll the dice (a single D6) and move you car - the game is as simple as that. Throw in a few event cards (good and bad) when you land on the "radio" spaces and hope not to land on the red spaces. That's all the rules in this game!
A double sided board for two different tracks on a game of luck suitable mainly for young kids.

item.description:
Roll the diamant die (a transparent d8) to determine the goal-number (= die roll + 4). Then any player is dealt this number of cards from the shuffled deck, that contains the various body parts: feet, legs, torsos, shoulders, and heads in lots of length and combinations.

Your goal is to build a "Langer Lulatsch" (Beanpole) with the right length (the goal-number as number of cards) to get the most points in the round (goal-number +3). Everyone who finishes a correct Lulatsch within the same trun, gets the number of cards of his figure.

The problem is to decide when to add which cards to your figure, as you have only one action per round deciding wether to draw a new card while discarding an old one (either from the drawpile or one of the discardpiles) or "build" your figure. And for example not all feet go with all legs as some have trousers and other have not. Once built you can't change the features and you have to build from bottom to top.

There is another round until the first player gets 50 points.

A very popular game in China. Played with a standard deck of cards (including both jokers). The bidding to determine the "landlord" makes the game work well with 3 players. The other two players play against the player who is the "landlord".

item.description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

A licensed Hasbro Monopoly variant set in Puerto Rico.

item.description: This card game contains 7 families with 7 cards in each family + 3 trumphs. Each turn a player asks another player if he(she) has one particular card. If he has that card he has to give it away to the one asking for it and he can continue asking for cards. When you have all cards from one family you can put it down in front of you. The goal of the game is to collect as many sets of families as possible.

item.description:
The strange name "Casuga Guina" stood for the initials of the surnames of the company designers and publishers: Manuel Calbet, Amando Suriñach, Manuel García, José Luis Guitián and Xavier Navarro. This Spanish company appeared in the mid 80s and published this and another title, Tutankhamon (see entry)

In "Troglodita", each player represents a prehistoric tribe that fights for survival and tries to occupy more caves than the others. In the meanwhile, they have to hunt, fish, confront wild animals, fight another tribes and suffer natural disasters such as earthquakes or epidemies. Obtaining fire is essential to keep food.

The game contents were poorly presented, but it was funny to play and it would have been really good with some extra work on rules and graphic design.

name.value: The Thorn Princess and the Four Knights
ibara no hime to yonnin no kishi

item.description:
Translated from the backside:
In this game, the players become royal knights, and their goal is to reclaim the princess who has shut herself into the Thorn Castle.
However, the princess is a selfish one, and she doesn't want to leave the Castle.
In order to get her out of there, the knights must earn her trust by pleasing (resolving) the selfish wishes she constantly repeats.

The knights use their cards to move around the board looking for useful things, awaiting the chance to take the princess with them. But once they claim the princess (for example, by defeating the knight she currently is accompanied by), she starts ranting "I'm hungry", "I want to rest" and other silly requests.
The winner is the player who succeeds in earning the princess' trust by clearing three of these requests and escorting her outside the castle's walls.

Contains:
A3 Game board
4 Knight cards
1 Princess card
84 Action cards
20 Event cards
20 Rant cards
6 cardboard figures (1 for each knight, 1 princess, 1 event marker)
1 6-sided die (the irriation counter)
24 item chips
1 rule book

Designed by Seiji Kanai
Illustrations by Noboru Sugiura

item.description:
Prophets Card Game is an LDS variation on Go Fish. Cards are numbered 1-13, with each number representing an LDS prophet. (The cards only go through Ezra Taft Benson.) There are also four suits, Beehives, Buffalo Skulls, Seagulls, and Wagon Wheels. Players ask others for the cards they need to complete the "Books" by asking for the name of the prophet pictured on the card.

The rules make note that this deck of cards is appropriate for other standard card games as well.
